title: Exaggerated, handwritten 1980's font
content:
Hi all --- I'm an artist who is very new to the world of fonts.

There is a font I've come across several times recently that was used in the 1980's and I need to replicate it. Can anyone lead me to a similar font?

I'm attaching a picture from the cover of the movie "Exposed".... it's the pink lettering.

Thanks VERY much in advance for any leads.

Best,  
Ryan

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111214114748im_/http:/typophile.com/files/photo_4476.jpg)

author: ryan.j.sullivan

comments.content:
In the 1980s there was apparently a device called a "brush", and with a substance called "ink" or "paint" one could make lettering like this. I've never used one myself, and I still don't understand how these "brushes" even interfaced with a computer, since they don't seem to have any wires, and wireless technology wasn't really that big back then.

- Lex

I would check parts 7 and 9 of [Mike Y's Script ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20111214114748/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/ScriptIDGuide.html) for fonts that might look similar.

- Lex

Just to give props to the original poster but they do note that it's handwritten - I think they could have been clearer in what they want though- which is, I assume, a font with a similar look and feel.

I can't think of any script fonts with such long connectors between the letters. You might be able to adapt Letraset's [Rapier](http://web.archive.org/web/20111214114748/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/letraset/rapier/) which is a late '80s design.

Also look through all these scripts by:  
 [Rob Leuschke](http://web.archive.org/web/20111214114748/http:/www.myfonts.com/person/leuschke/rob/),  
 [Charles Borges de Oliveira](http://web.archive.org/web/20111214114748/http:/www.myfonts.com/person/borges-de-oliveira/charles/)  
 [Sudtipos](http://web.archive.org/web/20111214114748/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/sudtipos/)

Your example looks as if it was done in some kind of crayon or pastel. If you want this exact look it will be even harder to match with a digital font. You might be better off getting a few different script fonts and use them as a starting point to draw your own lettering.

Thanks to all! I'm starting to think I should just replicate it by hand... which shouldn't be too difficult with a little digital manipulation afterwards.

Thanks again.
